intro: Euphrasia salisburgensis subsp. pulchra, commonly known as the Salzburg's beardtongue, is a flowering plant native to the alpine regions of Central Europe. It belongs to the Scrophulariaceae family and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh mountain environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental appeal and is often cultivated in gardens that mimic its natural habitat.
